title: Sydney father Jason Miller who lost limbs to sepsis may be forced to live in nursing home
text:
A father who lost both his hands and feet to sepsis claims he has been told he is not disabled enough to qualify for special accommodation.

Jason Miller, 49 - known to his family and friends as Buddy - almost died after developing a severe infection while in the Philippines last year.

The former Manly ferry operator survived but was forced to have his limbs amputated to stop the infection from spreading.

After 12 months rehabilitation Mr Miller is ready to move out of Sydney's Mona Vale Hospital and into his own place with his eight-year-old daughter Jhayda, who he has shared custody of.

However, he claims a health report which overstates his abilities - therefore excluding him from appropriate accommodation - has stopped him from 'getting on with his life'.

Scroll down for video

Jason Miller wants to move out of rehab and into a home with his eight-year-old daughter Jhayda (both pictured)

Mr Miller (pictured) almost died after developing a severe infection while in the Philippines last year

'(The report) makes me look like I could go for a jog,' he told Nine News.

'I shuffle and I can roll but that's not a lot. I can't put my legs on by myself… They shrink a bit (during the day) and I need help to put more socks on. Thankfully I have friends who can help.'

His report is currently being regraded, which may mean he can be able to afford an appropriate two-bedroom unit in Mona Vale that will allow him to live with his daughter Jhayda.

He faces another hurdle as there are limited spots available, he claims.

He told the Daily Telegraph the Mona Vale unit was the only specialist accommodation on the peninsula currently available.

'Mentally I've been strong throughout everything that has happened in the last 12 months, but this has cracked me,' he said.

'Some days I'm just not myself. I don't want to talk to anyone.

'At the moment I am looking at having to move into a nursing home until there is something else available.'

'We were told multiple times he has a less than 10 per cent chance of survival,' Kate Munn – Jason's sister-in-law – told Daily Mail Australia. 'Not just once or twice. Many times we were told he might not make it through the next few hours.'

'A true miracle': Buddy's fighting spirit came out in full force and to the surprise of doctors, nurses and his family, five days later he woke up

Jason Miller (pictured), 49 - known to his family and friends as Buddy - was admitted to hospital and within an hour he was fighting for his life in October last year

Mr Miller was flying back to Sydney in October last year when his health took a turn for the worst.

He initially thought it was the flu but when he was finally admitted to hospital he was put in a coma, diagnosed with a bacterial infection from both streptococcus and aerococcus that caused toxic shock syndrome and severe septic shock.

On advice from doctors that his heart would soon give out, the family also called in a priest to give him his last rites.

Mr Miller (pictured) had both his hands and both feet amputated in a bid to stop the infection from spreading

WHAT IS SEPSIS? Sepsis is a potentially life-threatening condition caused by the body's response to an infection. The body normally releases chemicals into the bloodstream to fight an infection. It occurs when the body's response to these chemicals is out of balance, triggering changes that can damage multiple organ systems. Symptoms include fever, difficulty breathing, low blood pressure, fast heart rate and mental confusion.

But Mr Miller's fighting spirit came out in full force and to the surprise of doctors, nurses and his family, five days later he woke up.

His positive attitude has been called inspiring by health care workers.

He said he feels lucky just be alive.

'Sepsis attacked my body, the adrenaline and sepsis shrunk my veins and my limbs all turned black and I lost my hands and I lost my feet, but I got my life back so that was alright,' he told Seven News.

Despite Mr Miller's claims, an NDIS spokesperson said he has been approved for specialist accommodation.

'The NDIA will continue to work with Mr Miller to ensure he is able to access appropriate accommodation and other disability-related supports he needs,' the spokesperson said.

authors: Kelsey Wilkie For Daily Mail Australia
